Japan Received 3 October 1995: revised 27 February 1996; accepted 29 February 1996 Abstract At high Ni contents ranging from 70 to 80 wt.%, Ni-MgO catalysts prepared by using a melt of the corresponding nitrates and citric acid were found to have high nickel surface area. and 3 exhibited catalytic activities for the hydrogenolysis of cyclohexane at _ 50 C. Keywords: Ni-MgO; Preparation; Citric acid; Cyclohexane; Hydrogenolysis Citric acid is utilized for preparing ceramics powder with high crystallinity [1,2]. This technique is known as an amorphous citrate process, and is also applied to prepare solid catalysts such as perovskite-type [3-6] and spinel-type composite oxides [7-9]. This technique, however, has not been applied to the preparation of supported metal catalysts, except for copper metal catalysts [4,7-9]. Although nickel metal catalysts are well known to have efficient activities for such reactions as hydrogenolysis [10] and hydrogenation [11,12], a Ni-MgO system is generally less active in comparison with the other supported Ni catalysts [12]. This is believed to be caused by the facts that both NiO and MgO have the same crystal structure of sodium chloride type, and their mixture is readily made into a solid solution [13]. In this paper, we describe the physical and catalytic activities of Ni-MgO catalyst prepared by using citric acid of which use let us expect a homogeneity of the resulting catalysts over a wide range of Ni/Mg ratio. * Corresponding author. Each Ni-MgO sample with different Ni contents was prepared by an essentially the same method as the amorphous citrate processes [1,2]. After a mixture of nickel nitrate and magnesium nitrate with a desired ratio had been melted with citric acid equimolar to the sum of nickel and magnesium ions at 70 without using solvents, the mixture was evacuated under a pressure of 0.7 kPa at 70. It was gradually solidified, and then expanded to about twentyfold apparent volume. After the resulting solid had been heated in air at 160 for 1 h, it was calcined in air at 500 for 3 h to give a NiO-MgO sample. The hydrogenolysis of cyclohexane was performed in a standard fixed bed-flow reactor under hydrogen flow (74 mmol. h-I) at a reaction temperature of 350, after the NiO-MgO sample (0.15 g) had been reduced at 500 for 2 h. The catalytic activity was evaluated in terms of the conversion of cyclohexane (flow rate: 17 mmol. h-~) when the catalytic activity had been attained at the steady state after cyclohexane fed for 30 rain. Hydrogen chemisorption was done by using a volumetric apparatus at 0 to calculate nickel metal surface area [14]. A total surface area of the sample was calculated by BET method using nitrogen isotherm at - 196. Table 1 summarizes physical properties of Ni-MgO samples prepared from a melt of the corresponding nitrates and citric acid. A total surface area of the unreduced NiO-MgO sample decreased monotonously with increase in Ni content. In contrast to the total surface area, Ni surface area calculated from the amount of hydrogen chemisorption increased linearly with Ni content at Ni contents below 60 wt.%. In the range between 70 and 80 wt.%, the Ni surface area was anomalously large. Fig. 1 shows a variation in catalytic activities with Ni content in Ni-MgO catalysts. The conversion of cyclohexane (curve a) increased with Ni content, and has a maximum at a Ni content of 70 wt.%. At a reaction temperature of 350, dehydrogenation of cyclohexane to benzene was also catalysed parallel to the hydrogenolysis to methane. The yield of benzene (curve b) increased with S. In contrast to the monotonous change in the cyclohex- ane conversion for the low Ni-content catalysts, high Ni-content catalysts (70-80 wt.%) showed high conversion of cyclohexane into methane. The variation in the cyclohexane conversion has been found to be similar to the variation in Ni surface area described in Table 1. In contrast to the low Ni-content catalysts, at a high Ni content of 70 wt.%, the Ni-MgO prepared by this method exhibited much higher activities for the cyclohexane hydrogenolysis than other reference Ni-MgO catalysts which were prepared by coprecipitation and by direct melting of the correspond- ing nitrates without using citric acid. As shown in Table 1, for the 70 and 80 wt.% Ni-containing catalysts prepared by this method, total surface areas were 50 and 45 m2g- 1, and Ni surface areas were 19 and 18 mZg-1, respectively. This indicates that about 40% of the catalyst surface is occupied by metallic Ni surface, and that Ni metal has been highly dispersed on the catalyst surface. When a sample with a Ni content of 70 wt.% was prepared without using citric acid, the total surface area was 22 mZg 1, and the Ni surface area was 3.7 mZg-l. In this case, only 17% of the surface is occupied by metallic Ni surface. Citric acid used in the preparation probably acts as a binder which heightens homogeneity of the resulting metal oxides of NiO and MgO. Therefore, high Ni surface area was attained on the reduced catalyst sample without aggregation of Ni metal particles. In conclusion, Ni-MgO catalysts prepared from a melt of the nitrates and citric acid were found to have high Ni surface areas at Ni contents ranging from 70 to 80 wt.% and to catalyse the hydrogenolysis of cyclohexane at 350.
